titleInfo.title: Characteristics of Mini Supercells in the Midwest

name.namePart: Department of Earth, Ocean, and Atmospheric Science

mods:mods.abstract: Mini supercell thunderstorms are similar in structure to traditional supercells, but they are smaller both vertically and horizontally. Despite their diminished spatial dimensions, mini supercells can produce severe hazards although the hazards typically are less intense than those of their larger counterparts. These storms commonly occur in tropical cyclones (TCs), but they also occur over land, particularly over the Midwest United States. Research on land-based mini supercells is limited relative to TC-related counterparts, with previous work consisting mostly of individual case studies. This research examines the environmental and radar-derived characteristics of 21 land-based mini supercells located in the Midwest region of the United States. Results are compared to previous studies of both traditional and land-based mini supercells. Environments of the 21 cases are assessed using data from the High-Resolution Rapid Refresh model (HRRR). The mean environment of the dataset exhibits high shear (0-6 km shear > 20 m s^(-1)) and low buoyancy (surface-based CAPE < 1000 J 〖kg〗^(-1)). This finding is mostly consistent with results of previous studies of land-based mini supercells, but there is some disagreement involving some parameters such as 0-3 km SRH. Outlier cases in this study indicate that mini supercell environments may be more variable than previously thought. Radar-derived characteristics of the mini supercells are assessed using WSR-88D data. Results generally are consistent with previous research on land-based mini supercells. However, values of rotational velocity (Vrot) are smaller than those reported for traditional supercells. Conversely, values of azimuthal shear are comparable to those of traditional supercells. Subsequently, shear-related warning thresholds are found to be more useful than thresholds utilizing Vrot for land-based mini supercells. The spatial dimensions of our mini supercells are found to be comparable to previous mini supercells. However, some outlying echo tops are very low. Results from this study hopefully will improve forecasters' ability to identify favorable environments for these storms and to warn appropriately when they occur.
mods:mods.note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Earth, Ocean, and Atmospheric Sciences in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
Henry E. Fuelberg, Professor Directing Thesis; Robert Hart, Committee Member; Guosheng Liu, Committee Member.
